case_title: JAHANGIR KHAN AND 2 OTHERS vs THE STATE

accussed_details.name: Jahangir Khan
allegation: Failure to comply with land surrender requirements under the Land Reforms Act, 1977

accussed_details.name: Jahanzaib Khan
allegation: Ownership of land involved in exchange application

accussed_details.name: Humayun Khan
allegation: Ownership of land involved in exchange application

complaint_summary: Jahangir Khan submitted an application for land exchange under the Land Reforms Act, 1977, which was rejected by the Deputy Land Commissioner on procedural grounds.
investigation_summary: The Deputy Land Commissioner rejected the application due to the absence of affidavits from petitioners Nos. 2 and 3 and conflicting claims from Major Nazar Hussain regarding the land in question.
judgment_summary: The court set aside the Deputy Land Commissioner's order due to procedural defects, including failure to notify and hear petitioners Nos. 2 and 3, and remanded the case for fresh decision.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition accepted; case remanded for fresh decision.
legal_arguments: Revision not barred under subsection (3) of section 4 of the Land Reforms Act, 1977.
Principle of natural justice violated as petitioners Nos. 2 and 3 were not heard.

assets.description: Land owned by Jahanzaib Khan and Humayun Khan

witness_statement.Major Nazar Hussain: Claimed ownership of the land in question, purchased for Rs. 2,72,000.

key_issues: Whether revision is barred under subsection (3) of section 4.
Failure to notify and hear petitioners Nos. 2 and 3.
Procedural irregularities in the application process.

maxims.Natural Justice: No one should be deprived of property without being heard.

legal_terms.Revision: A judicial review of a lower court's decision.
legal_terms.Affidavit: A written statement confirmed by oath or affirmation.

words_and_phrases.Procedural Defect: Failure to follow prescribed legal procedures.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around procedural defects in the land exchange application under the Land Reforms Act, 1977. The court emphasized the principle of natural justice and remanded the case for fresh decision.
